conclusion: Determine the speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds using the acceleration-time graph.
Graph shows acceleration as a function of time; y-axis is acceleration in m/s^2, x-axis is time in seconds.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 1 m/s^2.
From t = 1 to t = 4 seconds, acceleration is constant at 1 m/s^2.
From t = 4 to t = 5 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 1 to 0 m/s^2.
From t = 5 to t = 55 seconds, acceleration is 0 m/s^2 (constant velocity).
From t = 55 to t = 56 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -1 m/s^2.
From t = 56 to t = 59 seconds, acceleration is constant at -1 m/s^2.
From t = 59 to t = 60 seconds, acceleration increases linearly from -1 to 0 m/s^2.
Calculate speed at t = 1 second: v_1 = 1 m/s.
Calculate speed at t = 4 seconds: v_4 = 4 m/s.
Calculate speed at t = 5 seconds: v_5 = 4.5 m/s.
Speed remains constant at t = 55 seconds: v_5 = 4.5 m/s.
Calculate speed at t = 56 seconds: v_56 = 4 m/s.
